content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.Bromine is the only nonmetal that exists as a liquid at room temperature and <math alttext="1 atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>atm</mtext></math>.(a) Write the complete ground-state electron configuration of a bromine atom.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.Bromine is the only nonmetal that exists as a liquid at room temperature and <math alttext="1 atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>atm</mtext></math>.(a) Write the complete ground-state electron configuration of a bromine atom.

(b) Following is a partial photoelectron spectrum <math alttext="(P E S)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfenced><mi>PES</mi></mfenced></math> showing only the core electrons in bromine.(i) Circle the peak in the spectrum that corresponds to the <math alttext="3 s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>s</mi></math> electrons of bromine.

(ii) Both bromine and krypton have <math alttext="18" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>18</mn></math> core electrons. Would the peaks for the core electrons in the <math alttext="P E S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>PES</mi></math> of krypton be shifted to the right, shifted to the left, or remain unchanged as compared to those in the <math alttext="P E S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>PES</mi></math> of bromine? Explain your reasoning.

Elemental bromine, <math alttext="B r 2, liquid" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Br</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>l</mi></mfenced></math>, is produced in the reaction represented by the following chemical equation. <math alttext="C l 2, gas, plus 2 B r with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, react to produce B r 2, liquid, plus 2 C l with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>Cl</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mfenced> <mi>g</mi> </mfenced> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <msup> <mi>Br</mi> <mo>-</mo> </msup> <mfenced> <mrow> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> </mrow> </mfenced> <mo>→</mo> <msub> <mi>Br</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mfenced> <mi>l</mi> </mfenced> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <msup> <mi>Cl</mi> <mo>-</mo> </msup> <mfenced> <mrow> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> </mrow> </mfenced> </math> (c) A student claims that elemental chlorine, <math alttext="C l 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Cl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced></math>, is reduced in this reaction. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer in terms of oxidation numbers.

The overall reaction, related half-cell reactions, and standard reduction potentials are given in the following table. Reaction <math alttext="E naught, in volts" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi><mo>°</mo><mo> </mo><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mfenced></math> <math alttext="C l 2, gas, plus 2 B r with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, react to produce B r 2, liquid, plus 2 C l with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mtext>Cl</mtext> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mfenced> <mi>g</mi> </mfenced> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <msup> <mi>Br</mi> <mo>-</mo> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo>→</mo> <msub> <mi>Br</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>l</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> <mo> </mo> <mspace width="-0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>+ </mtext> <mspace width="-0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>2 </mtext> <mspace width="-0.2em"> </mspace> <msup> <mi>Cl</mi> <mo>-</mo> </msup> <mfenced> <mrow> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> </mrow> </mfenced> </math> <math alttext="blank" overflow="scroll"> <mo>?</mo> </math> <math alttext="C l 2, liquid, plus 2 electrons, react to produce 2 C l with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Cl</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>g</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo mathvariant="italic"> </mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msup><mi>Cl</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> <math alttext="positive 1.36" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>1.36</mn></math> <math alttext="B r 2, liquid, plus 2 e with a negative 1 charge, react to produce 2 B r with a negative 1 charge, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Br</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mfenced><mi>l</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mi>Br</mi><msup><mo> </mo><mo>-</mo></msup><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> <math alttext="plus 1.07" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>1.07</mn></math> (d) Calculate the standard cell potential for the overall reaction between chlorine gas and bromide ions.

(e) Calculate the value of the standard Gibbs free energy (in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole sub reaction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>kJ</mi><mo>/</mo><msub><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math>) for the reaction between chlorine gas and bromide ions.

(f) At <math alttext="298 kelvin" overflow="scroll"> <mn>298</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi> </math>, is this reaction thermodynamically favorable? Justify your answer based on the standard change in Gibbs free energy you calculated in part (e).

(g) The standard enthalpy change of the reaction is <math alttext="delta H naught sub reaction, equals negative 91.2 kilojoules per mole sub reaction" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>∘</mo></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>91.2</mn><mo> </mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mo> </mo><msub><mtext>kJ/mol</mtext><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></math>. Calculate the standard entropy change for the reaction at <math alttext="298 kelvin" overflow="scroll"> <mn>298</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi> </math>. Include units with your answer.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
